results.notes:
R. cinnamomia was originally decribed in the Eastern US, but the type specimen has been lost. Description can be seen at:
http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/...
Growing gregariously from ground well covered in decayed, finely shredded woods, likely hardwood. 2-4cm, shrinking to 1-3 cm. Firm exterior, soft, marshmallowy interior that became gooey over time. Surface white changing to dull cinnamon brown with concolorous scales. Columella and radial pattern extending to edge of endoperidium clearly visible. Columella concolorous with gleba. Sterile base slightly convex above, attenuate below. Long, copious white rhizomes. Stained pinkish over time on the peridium. Endoperidium readily seperating from gleba upon dying. KOH was red to black on exterior, negative on interior. Iron salts were grey fading away on exterior, negative on interior.

results.notes:
Cortinarius lebre Garrido es un hongo comestible que es especialmente frecuente en el centro sur de Chile, donde se asocia principalmente con N. obliqua, pero también crece debajo de otros árboles del género Nothofagus.

El ejemplar de la fotografía se encontraba bajo N. obliqua. El epíteto se refiere al nombre nativo chileno de este hongo comestible: “Lebre” de consistencia dura y con el píleo de color violeta. Presenta un olor desagradable similar a una mezcla de alcanfor y naftaleno que a menudo se puede percibir a varios metros de distancia de los basidiomas.

results.notes:
Su nombre común es “Pinatra”, es un hongo parásito biotrófico, cuyos estromas crecen solitarios o en grupos distribuidos en hileras como se puede observar en las imágenes.

Los ejemplares maduros miden hasta 12 cm (es la Cyttaria más grande de las siete especies de este género presentes en Chile) y fructifican en primavera sobre árboles del género Nothofagus.

Estos ejemplares se encontraban creciendo sobre N. obliqua.

results.notes:
Presenta estromas globosos de menor tamaño que C. berteroi, no sobrepasando los 6 cm. Se encuentra en Chile y Argentina, con estromas esféricos y livianos, crece en grupos parasitando árboles del Nothofagus. Estos ejemplares fueron recolectados sobre N. obliqua.

Su recolección es lenta, ya que a veces se encuentran muy altos, por lo que hay que subirse a los árboles para recolectarlos o sacarlos cuidadosamente con una varilla larga.

results.notes:
Boletus loyo conocido comúnmente como “Loyo” es un hongo comestible de gran tamaño que forma ectomicorrizas con árboles del género Nothofagus. Presenta un píleo de color rojizo y un estípite de un color amarillo intenso, ancho y corto.

Sus cuerpos fructíferos son basidiomas solitarios o en pequeños grupos que aparecen sobre el suelo, generalmente, donde hay Murtilla (Ugni molinae).

Este ejemplar se encontraba bajo N. obliqua cerca de la Cordillera de Nahuelbuta.

results.notes:
This is the same mushroom as Observation 244343 and Observation 244233, found earlier than usual in the same pattern as everything else this year.

JP3 and I have talked about this mushroom extensively and now believe it to be B. pallidoroseus rather than B. bicolor. The only reason to doubt that ID (in my opinion) is the bright red shade of the cap and stipe rather than the paler pink described in the books. I believe that it’s the field description in need of revision rather than this ID. It should also be noted that these caps and stipes will readily fade into pink tones when they are covered with leaves or other debris.

A sample will be preserved at a lower temperature than prior years and sent on for analysis.

results.notes:
thallus C-; disk C+y/o

Note the soralia(!) There are several taxa in the L. rupicola group with soralia, as it turns out: L. rouxii (looks totally different), L. lojkeana (looks extremely similar, see photos by Stridvalls), and L. rupicola var. sorediata (thanks to Bruce McCune for bringing this name to my attention). L. lojkeana has the same capitate gray/black-peppered soralia, however it related to L. swartzii with a well-developed eucortex. While this specimen does have a distinct cortex, it is not nearly as well-developed as L. swartzii (I compared to a reference specimen I have from eastern Washington). And since L. bicincta was common in the vicinity, I conclude that this is “just” a sorediate form of L. bicincta. L. rupicola var. sorediata is probably the correct name for this, since L. bicincta is almost certainly a synonym of L. rupicola. (The blackened inner excipular ring is highly variable, sometimes within a single thallus, depending on exposure.)

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Spores amyloid, 7.5-9.5 × 5.5-7.

Several different taxa are currently proposed for the North American Blushing Amanita group. Comparing with numbered types found on the Amanita Studies Website, the ones seen in this observation appear to best match Amanita sp-amerirubescens02 http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita+sp-amerirubescens02 . But, it is perhaps currently unclear if the numbered taxa correlate with different sets of morphological traits. The observations of 02 documented on ASW all mention the presence of conifers in the habitat.

There have been observations made in North America of Amanita rubescens var. alba that exhibit tan to light brown cap surface (although I doubt the mushrooms seen in this observation represent this species).

NAMP accession #58756.

results.notes:
Cap is light brown with pinkish tones, sometimes cracking in older specimens. Flesh of cap and stem is yellowish, with some pink tones. Stem has reddish longitudinal striations. Pores are yellow, rapidly bruising blue and pores are depressed around stem. Flesh of stem and cap quickly bruises blue when cut or damaged [minutes, not seconds]. Tube layer separates easily. Grows in grass (lawn) fully exposed to sun. Taste is not bitter.

UPDATE: surface of cap is dry, context overall is light and foamy. Caps of adjacent mushrooms are sometimes fused together. I consumed a small amount after cooking with no ill effects. The caps taste slightly acrid, but the stems less so.

results.notes: Four rosette shaped specimens clustered on buried wood and wood chips near the base of a mature Honey Locust tree in residential neighborhood, appearing terrestrial. Fertile surface has irregular pores that appear mazelike from some angles. KOH was negative. I obtained a white spore print.

results.notes: A fairy ring of nearly a dozen specimens in grass on the common ground of a residential community. Largest cap: 24 cm. Stipe: 24 cm. See Image #7769.

results.notes: Growing under Swamp Chestnut Oak (Q. michauxii); mature specimen. Viscid when wet, tuberculate towards margin. Grey/buff/tan, speckled with orange/red/cinnamon spots. Stem smooth, white becoming very hollow and cavernous. Odor weak, farinaceous.
results.location_name: Stockbridge, Henry Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: Growing alone, by oak in damp soil (little grass, some liter). Cap margin slightly striate, dingy white with darker margin and pale/grey warts on disc. Gills very close, short gills frequent and with irregular length. Sturdy annulus, stipe browning towards base. Bulbous base with strong browning. Spores infrequently globose to largely subglobose, smooth. 7.25-8.5 × 7-9
results.location_name: Stockbridge, Henry Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: Growing near juniper and oak. Flesh white, bruising strong blue. Pores pale yellow, bruising blue quickly.
results.location_name: Stockbridge, Henry Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: Growing by oak. Cap very sticky following rain. Margin strongly striate-tuberculate. Cinnamon-brown spotted around cap. Gills whitish/cream, forked near stem mainly, infrequently near margin. Stipe smooth, dry; becoming cavernous/hollow w/ strong brown bruising/spotting. Spores broadly ellipsoid to infrequently subglobose, with mainly isolated warts, connecting lines essentially absent. 7-8.8 × 6-7

results.notes:
This is the same park where observation 243818 came from but I am not at all sure it is the same species. The main distinguishing features are forming the red on the stipe in a different way (this is spotted and that is streaked) and certain differences in the chemical tests. Whether the same or different the red-and-yellow boletes found in this location have a common name around Pittsburgh courtesy of John Plischke III: “That weird Pine Ridge Bicolor.” It’s just… different from ones found elsewhere.

Notable for this find include (a) forming it’s red stipe from dots and spots seen here; (b) slowly bruising green on the stipe when rubbed; © being known as a sickener, with at least one confirmed victim for this spotted-stalk version; and (d) having a cap that seems to turn red indifferently or not at all. With regard to the last, this observation includes a pair of babies growing mere inches apart, one of which has a full red cap and the other a straight tan cap. Neither was covered or had any other observable differences in their environment. Continuing, (e) the specimens tend to appear in great numbers when they come up, and (f) they reach unusual size compared to most bicolors I have seen. The largest, uncollectably old specimen I found this time had a cap that was almost 10” across.

These are a typical bolete when it comes to texture, odor, taste, and heft. They get quite marshmallowy in old age but otherwise have average firmness.

No particular odor or taste was noted.

Found in grass between oak trees about 10-20 feet into the woods alongside a mowed clearing. The weather has been moderately rainy but the ground underfoot was not wet.

Mycelium was white.

Cap flesh was pale yellow, approaching white in the caps. Larval tunnels were dark red. The flesh did not turn blue in any notable way.

Thin pore layer was yellow, bruised blue/black after about 5-10 seconds, and maintained the dark color several hours later. Older specimens may have bruised a bit more readily than younger ones.

NOTE ON PHOTOS: All chemical tests go in the order ammonia, then KOH, then FeSO4 moving from left to right

Ammonia on Red Cap Skin: Faded to yellow/tan.
Ammonia on Tan Cap Skin: No strong reaction.
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No strong reaction.
Ammonia on Young Pores: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Old Pores: No reaction.
Ammonia on Cap Context: Turned pale pink. (Observation 243818 had no reaction).
Ammonia on Stipe Context: Turned pale pink. (Observation 243818 had no reaction).
KOH on Red Cap Skin: Turned yellow. (Observation 243818 turned orange).
KOH on Tan Cap Skin: No strong reaction. (Observation 243818 turned orange).
KOH on Stipe Skin: Turned red. (Observation 243818 turned faint yellow orange).
KOH on Young Pores: Turned orange.
KOH on Old Pores: Turned red/orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Turned orange.
KOH on Stipe Context: Turned orange.
FeSO4 on Red Cap Skin: Turned olive.
FeSO4 on Tan Cap Skin: Turned olive.
FeSO4 on Stipe Skin: Turned olive.
FeSO4 on Young Pores: Turned olive brown.
FeSO4 on Old Pores: Turned black.
FeSO4 on Cap Context: Turned olive.
FeSO4 on Stipe Context: Turned olive.

results.notes:
Cap surface radially textured, grayish-green with light purplish areas along the margin. Cuticle peeling to ~50% of radius.

Stipe white.

Gills flexible, some forking near the stipe. Lamellulae occasionally partially connected to longer gills, creating the impression of forking. Not sure whether this qualifies as “forking near the margin”.

Spores approximately 6.5-8 × 5-6, within the reported range of R. cyanoxantha (although maximum lengths smaller that reported for cyanoxantha). Spore dimensions significantly smaller than for R. variata. Amyloid warts smaller than 1 micron. Spore print white.

Old-growth forest near a stream, hemlock, oak, white pine.

NAMP accession #58760.

results.notes:
At first I did not think these represented the species Amanita crenulata. The caps feature more yellow than I expect with crenulata, each small specimen had a persistent annulus, and the stipe bases featured more hefty deposits than I generally see with crenulata. In general, the basal bulb of crenulata shows (at most) a pigmented powdery deposit. But, reading the description of crenulata on the Amanita Studies Website, I see that a white “collar” atop the basal bulb of crenulata may represent the limbus internus. This appears to be consistent with the stipe bases seen in this observation.

Universal veil deposits on cap are consistent with crenulate, as are the short-striate cap margins.

Gills are narrowly attached to stipe, consistent with crenulata.

Spore morphology fits crenulata, with Q maybe on the small side. Spores not amyloid; globose, subglobose, broadly elliptical, 7-9.5 × 7-9.

On a lawn near spruce. Pine and oak in the vicinity.

Amanita crenulata is typically considered to be a late summer taxon (although examples which may represent early-season collections have shown up on MO).

NAMP accession #58761.

Link to NAMP sequence https://mycomap.com/...
